required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of an Endoscopic Bite Block on Mask Ventilation
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of an Endoscopic Bite Block on Mask Ventilation in Anesthetized and Paralyzed Patients

brief_summary.textblock: Evaluation of effects of an endoscopic bite block on mask ventilation. In the present study, expiratory tidal volume and minute ventilation are measured under same pressure controlled mode in ventilator with three kinds of holding a mask. ( by one hand, one hand with an endoscopic bite block and two hand hold.)

detailed_description.textblock: Evaluation of effects of an endoscopic bite block on mask ventilation. In the present study, expiratory tidal volume and minute ventilation are measured under the same pressure controlled mode in ventilator (Pressure 15cmH2O, Respiratory rate 15/min, I:E=1:1) with three kinds of holding a mask. ( by one hand, one hand with an endoscopic bite block and two hand hold.)

primary_outcome.time_frame: during mask ventilation after anesthesia induction
primary_outcome.description: Expiratory tidal volume with one-hand mask ventilation, one-handed mask ventilation with an endoscopic bite block, and two-handed ventilation

secondary_outcome.time_frame: during mask ventilation after anesthesia induction
secondary_outcome.description: Minute ventilationwith one-hand mask ventilation, one-handed mask ventilation with an endoscopic bite block, and two-handed ventilation

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of inadequate ventilation or dead space ventilation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: during mask ventilation after anesthesia induction
secondary_outcome.description: Inadequate mask ventilation and dead-space ventilation are defined as a mean expiratory tidal volume of less than 4 mL kgâˆ’1 of predicted body weight and a mean expiratory tidal volume of less than 150 mL per breath with no clinical signs, respectively.

arm_group.description: A fitting mask is held by one hand -> one hand with an endoscopic bite block -> held by two hands
A fitting mask is held by one hand -> held by two hands-> one hand with an endoscopic bite block
A fitting mask is held by one hand with an endoscopic bite block->by one hand -> by two hands
A fitting mask is held by one hand with an endoscopic bite block -> by two hands-> one hand
A fitting mask is held by two hands -> one hand -> one hand with an endoscopic bite block
A fitting mask is held by two hands ->one hand with an endoscopic bite block-> by one hand

intervention.description: mask ventilation (one-handed ventilation, one-handed with an endoscopic bite block, and two-handed ventilation)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients scheduled for elective surgery under general anesthesia and agree with the purpose of the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients with diseases or structural abnormalities in the upper airway, wobbly teeth, and limited mouth opening of less than 3.5 cm or those who were at risk of aspiration

overall_official.affiliation: Seoul Metropolitan Government Seoup National University Boramae Medical Center

facility.name: Seoul Metropolitan Government Seoul National University Boramae Medical Center

reference.citation: Hart D, Reardon R, Ward C, Miner J. Face mask ventilation: a comparison of three techniques. J Emerg Med. 2013 May;44(5):1028-33. doi: 10.1016/j.jemermed.2012.11.005. Epub 2013 Mar 7.

Joffe AM, Hetzel S, Liew EC. A two-handed jaw-thrust technique is superior to the one-handed "EC-clamp" technique for mask ventilation in the apneic unconscious person. Anesthesiology. 2010 Oct;113(4):873-9. doi: 10.1097/ALN.0b013e3181ec6414.
Walsh JH, Maddison KJ, Platt PR, Hillman DR, Eastwood PR. Influence of head extension, flexion, and rotation on collapsibility of the passive upper airway. Sleep. 2008 Oct;31(10):1440-7.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Associate professor, Department of Anesthesiology and Pain medicine
